wordpressPost.title: Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup 5/8/2015
wordpressPost.content:
The WeSpire Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup aggregates the top employee engagement articles from around the industry to keep you informed and inspire positive impact in your organization.

The Top Cities For Employee Engagement

As part of Quantum Workplace’s recent 2015 Employee Engagement Trends Report, the organization looked at data collected for 40 cities as part of America’s 2014 Best Places to Work initiative. With more than 440K employees at 5.5K companies, results showed that close to 75% of cities reviewed saw declines in employee engagement compared to last year and the cities with the highest engagement include Nashville, Sacramento, Huntsville, and Washington D.C.

How Corporate Social Responsibility is Moving From Optional to Mandatory

At the recent 2015 Oslo Business for Peace Summit, global leaders discussed the future of business and honored individuals whose work marries profit to a higher purpose. Arif Naqvi, the keynote speaker summed up the importance of sustainability by saying, Sustainability for business today is not a nice-to-do thing’It’s become crucial to a company’s ability to show that it has a right to exist.

Millennials want to work for employers committed to values and ethics

According to Global Tolerance consultancy, almost half of the UK workforce (42%) now want to work for an organization that has a positive impact on the world. The organization believes the research suggests that change is being driven by Millennials’those born between 1981-1996’because 62% have indicated they want to work for a company that makes a positive impact. What does this mean? That Millennials are changing the landscape of work not only in the US, but across the globe.

U.S. Employee Engagement Holds Steady at 31.7%

The percentage of U.S. employees engaged in their jobs in April averaged 31.7%. The stat is consistent with March and January’s numbers but lower than the 3-year high Gallup saw in February. Perhaps the most interesting finding was that when broken down by education level, Gallup found that workers with advanced degrees are the least engaged in their jobs (29.1% vs 36.1% of employees with a high school diploma or less).

CSR is dead, part 3: Blazing a trail to business transformation

The final installment in a bold three-part series on the state of CSR argues that to deliver big changes in sustainability, businesses need to approach the challenge differently. Sustainability principles need to be integrated into every aspect of business, therefore ending the need for separate CSR departments. The author urges companies to follow Unilever’s recent example, and make sustainability part of everybody’s job by closing down organizational CSR units.
